case_name: Management of the Chandramalai Estate v. Union of the workmen

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 347/1959 filed by the management of Chandramalai Estate.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the Award dated October 17,1957, of the Industrial Tribunal No. 11, Ernakulam, in Industrial Dispute No. 63 of 1956.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the Award dated October 17, 1957 of Industrial Tribunal No. 11, Ernakulam in Industrial Dispute No. 63 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the Award dated October 17,1957, of the Industrial Tribunal No. 11, Ernakulam, in Industrial Dispute No. 63 of 1956.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on April 4, 1960 by DAS GUPTA, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1960. April 4. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by DAS GUPTA, J.-

facts.text: On August 9, 1955, the Union of the workmen of the Chandramalai Estate submitted a memorandum containing fifteen demands to the Manager.

anchor.surface_text: On August 9, 1955, the Union of the workmen of the Chandramalai Estate submitted to the Manager of the Estate a memorandum containing fifteen demands.

facts.text: Management agreed to fulfil some demands but principal demands remained unsatisfied.

anchor.surface_text: Though the management agreed to fulfil some of the demands the principal demands remained unsatisfied.

facts.text: Labour Officer, Trichur advised mutual negotiations between management and workers.

anchor.surface_text: On August 29, 1955, the Labour Officer, Trichur, who had in the meantime been apprised of the position by both the management of the Estate as well as the Labour Union advised mutual negotiations between the representatives of the management and workers.

facts.text: Matter recommended by Labour Officer to Conciliation Officer, Trichur.

anchor.surface_text: Ultimately the matter was recommended by the Labour Officer to the Conciliation Officer, Trichur, for conciliation.

facts.text: Conciliation efforts failed, last meeting held on November 30, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The Conciliation Officers efforts proved in vain. The last meeting for Conciliation appears to have been held on November 30, 1955.

facts.text: Union gave strike notice on following day (December 1, 1955), workmen went on strike from December 9, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: On the following day the Union gave a strike notice and the workmen went on a strike with effect from December 9, 1955.

facts.text: Strike ended on January 5, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The strike ended on January 5, 1956.

facts.text: Government referred the dispute as regards five demands to Industrial Tribunal, Trivandrum prior to January 5, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Prior to this, on January 5, the Government had referred the dispute as regards five of the demands for adjudication to the Industrial Tribunal, Trivandrum.

facts.text: By order dated June 11, 1956, dispute withdrawn from Trivandrum Tribunal and referred to Industrial Tribunal, Ernakulam.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter by an order dated June 11, 1956, the dispute was withdrawn from the Trivandrum Tribunal and referred to the Industrial Tribunal, Ernakulam.

facts.text: Tribunal awarded dated October 17, 1957 granted workers' demands on all issues.

anchor.surface_text: By its award dated October 17, 1957, the Tribunal granted the workmens demands on all these issues.

facts.text: After rice decontrol in April 1954 by Travancore Cochin Government, management sold rice to workers charging 12 annas per measure excess for rice beyond 1-1/2 measure per head.

anchor.surface_text: On the first issue the workmens case was that after the control on rice was lifted by the Travancore Cochin Government in April, 1954, the management which continued to sell rice to the workmen, charged at the excessive rate of 12 annas per measure for rice bought in excess of a quota for 1-1/2 measure per head.

facts.text: Management claimed workers not bound to buy rice from estate and only cost price charged.

anchor.surface_text: The managements case was that the workmen were not bound to buy rice from the Estates management and secondly, that only the actual cost price and not any excess had been charged.

facts.text: Tribunal held management charged more than cost price based on documents and ordered refund.

anchor.surface_text: The tribunal held on a consideration of oral and documentary evidence that the management had charged more than the cost price and held that they were bound to refund the same.

facts.text: Chandramalai Tea Estate situated at high altitude, customary to pay blanket allowance in region.

anchor.surface_text: The second issue was in respect of a claim for cumbly allowance. Chandramalai Tea Estate is situated at a high altitude. It is not disputed that it had been customary for the Estates in this region to pay blanket allowance to workmen...

facts.text: Management stopped blanket allowance from 1949 onwards, resumed in 1954.

anchor.surface_text: But in spite of it the management of this Estate stopped payment of the allowance from 1949 onwards and resumed payment only in 1954.

facts.text: No dispute raised about blanket allowance till August 9, 1955 (management defence).

anchor.surface_text: The managements defence was that any dispute not having been raised about this till August 9, 1955, there was no reason for raising it at this late stage.

facts.text: Tribunal awarded blanket allowance Rs. 39 per workman for 1949-1953.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal rejected this contention and awarded cumbly allowance of Rs. 39 per workman-made up of Rs. 7 per year for the years 1949, 1950 and 1951 and Rs. 9 per year for the years 1952 and 1953.

facts.text: Workmen claimed strike justified, management claimed illegal and unjustified.

anchor.surface_text: On the third issue while the workmen pleaded that the-strike was justified the management contended that it was illegal and unjustified.

facts.text: Tribunal held both parties to blame, ordered 50% emoluments for strike period.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal held that both parties were to blame for the strike and ordered the management to pay workers 50 of their total emoluments for the strike period.

facts.text: Government referred dispute on January 3, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The Government appear to have acted quickly and referred the dispute on January 3, 1956.

facts.text: Strike called off after government reference.

anchor.surface_text: It was after this that the strike was called off.

facts.text: Court held strike unjustified, workmen not entitled to wages for strike period.

anchor.surface_text: We are bound to hold in view of the circumstances mentioned above that the Tribunal erred in holding that the strike was at least partially justified... the strike was unjustified and so the workmen are not entitled to any wages for the strike period.

facts.text: Court upheld tribunal award on rice excess price refund and blanket allowance.

anchor.surface_text: The award in so far as it directed refund of the excess amount collected... cannot therefore be successfully challenged... The Tribunals award on this issue also is therefore maintained.

facts.text: Blanket allowance regularly paid year after year till stopped in 1949 (admitted).

anchor.surface_text: The admitted fact that it had been regularly paid year after year for many years till it was stopped in 1949...

facts.text: Management opened shop to help workmen sell rice.

anchor.surface_text: The fact that workmen were not compelled to purchase rice from the management is hardly material the management had opened the shop to help the workmen...

issues.text: Was the price realised by the management for the rice sold to the workers after decontrol excessive and if so, are the workers entitled to get refund of the excessive value so companylected?

anchor.surface_text: Was the price realised by the management for the rice sold to the workers after decontrol excessive and if so, are the workers entitled to get refund of the excessive value so companylected?

issues.text: Are the workers entitled to get cumbly allowance with retrospective effect from the date it was stopped and what should be the rate of such allowance?

anchor.surface_text: Are the workers entitled to get cumbly allowance with retrospective effect from the date it was stopped and what should be the rate of such allowance?

issues.text: Are the workers entitled to get wages for the period of the strike ?

anchor.surface_text: 3. Are the workers entitled to get wages for the period of the strike ?

issues.text: whether the tribunal was right in awarding 50 of emoluments to the workmen for the strike period

anchor.surface_text: This brings us to the question whether the tribunal was right in awarding 50 of emoluments to the work. men for the strike period.
We are unable to see how the strike in such circumstances companyld be held to be justified.

arguments.claim: Strike hasty; should have requested government reference under ID Act before striking; demands not urgent

anchor.surface_text: It has been urged on behalf of the appellant that there was nothing in the nature of the demands to justify such hasty action and in fairness the Union should have taken the formal and reasonable course provided by law by asking the Government to make a reference under the Industrial Disputes Act before it decided to strike.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: f demand a strike can be companymenced with impunity without exhausting reasonable avenues for peaceful achievement of their objects. There may be cas

arguments.claim: Strike legitimate weapon but indiscriminate hasty use not encouraged; should exhaust reasonable avenues like reference

anchor.surface_text: While on the one hand it has to be remembered that strike is a legitimate and sometimes unavoidable weapon in the hands of labour it is equally important to remember that indiscriminate and hasty use of this weapon should not be encouraged.

arguments.claim: Strike unjustified as did not wait after conciliation failure for government reference

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to see how the strike in such circumstances could be held to be justified. The Tribunal itself appears to have been in two minds on the question. ... the strike was unjustified and so the workmen are not entitled to any wages for the strike period.

holdings.text: The Tribunal's conclusions of fact regarding the cost price of rice and the price realised by the management are correct and not to be interfered with.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to see anything that would justify us in interfering with these conclusions of facts. Indeed the documents on which the Tribunal has based its conclusions were not even made part of the Paper-Book so that even if we had wanted to consider this question ourselves it would be impossible for us to do so. We are satisfied that the Tribunal was right in its conclusions as regards the cost price of rice to the manage- ment and the price actually realised by the management from workmen.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tribunal relied on management's own documents; documents absent from appeal record preventing interference.

holdings.text: Management must refund excess rice price charged to workers despite no compulsion to buy, as shop was for their help.

anchor.surface_text: The managements case that the workmen were charged only the cost price of rice has rightly been rejected by the Tribunal. The fact that workmen were not compelled to purchase rice from the management is hardly material the management had opened the shop to help the workmen and if it is found that it charged excess rates, in fairness, the workmen must be reimbursed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Fairness requires reimbursement of excess where management charged more than cost for rice supplied to aid workers.

holdings.text: Tribunal's award directing refund of excess rice amount collected cannot be challenged.

anchor.surface_text: The award in so far as it directed refund of the excess amount collected on the basis of the figures found by the Tribunal cannot therefore be successfully challenged.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Factual findings upheld; direction for refund proper.

holdings.text: Regular payment of cumbly allowance over years establishes it as part of conditions of service.

anchor.surface_text: The admitted fact that it had been regularly paid year after year for many years till it was stopped in 1949 is sufficient to establish the workmens case that payment of a proper cumbly allowance had become a part of their conditions of service.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Long-standing customary practice integrates into employment terms.

holdings.text: Management acted arbitrarily and illegally by stopping cumbly allowance payments from 1949-1954; laches no bar to relief.

anchor.surface_text: We do not think that the mere fact that the workmen did not raise any dispute on the managements refusal to implement this condition of service till August 9, 1955, would be a sufficient reason to refuse them such payment. The management had acted arbitrarily and illegally in stopping payment of these allowances from 1949 to 1954. They cannot now be heard to say that they should not be asked to pay it merely because the years have already gone by.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Unilateral arbitrary discontinuation of service condition requires retrospective payment; delay in demand irrelevant.

holdings.text: Tribunal's award of cumbly allowance at specified rates for 1949-1953 is maintained.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal has acted justly in directing payment of the allowances to the workmen for the years 1949 to 1953. The correctness of the rates awarded by the Tribunal is not challenged before us. The Tribunals award on this issue also is therefore maintained.

holdings.text: Strike is legitimate weapon but indiscriminate hasty use without exhausting legal remedies like government reference not justified.

anchor.surface_text: While on the one hand it has to be remembered that strike is a legitimate and sometimes unavoidable weapon in the hands of labour it is equally important to remember that indiscriminate and hasty use of this weapon should not be encouraged. It will not be right for labour to think that for any kind of demand a strike can be commenced with impunity without exhausting reasonable avenues for peaceful achievement of their objects.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Balance right to strike with policy against hasty action; exhaust conciliation and request reference first unless urgent.

holdings.text: The strike was unjustified as workers did not wait after conciliation failure to request government reference before striking.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to see how the strike in such circumstances could be held to be justified. The Tribunal itself appears to have been in two minds on the question. Its conclusion appears to be that the strike though not fully justified, was half justified and half unjustified we find it difficult to appreciate this curious concept of half justification.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Demands non-urgent; immediate strike after Nov 30 conciliation failure hasty despite quick govt reference on Jan 3.

holdings.text: Tribunal erred in holding strike partially justified and awarding 50% wages; workmen not entitled to any wages for strike period.

anchor.surface_text: We are bound to hold in view of the circumstances mentioned above that the Tribunal erred in holding that the strike was at least partially justified. The error is so serious that we are bound in the interests of justice to set aside the decision. There is, in our view, no escape from the conclusion that the strike was unjustified and so the workmen are not entitled to any wages for the strike period.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Wholly unjustified strike denies all wages; no partial justification concept.

holdings.text: Appeal allowed in part: set aside strike wages award, maintain rest.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore allow the appeal in part and set aside the award in so far as it directed the payment of 50 of the total emoluments for the strike period but maintain the rest of the award.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Partial reversal based on error in strike justification analysis.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to see anything that would justify us in interfering with these conclusions of facts. Indeed the documents on which the Tribunal has based its conclusions were not even made part of the Paper-Book so that even if we had wanted to consider this question ourselves it would be impossible for us to do so. We are satisfied that the Tribunal was right in its conclusions as regards the cost price of rice to the manage- ment and the price actually realised by the management from workmen.
We therefore allow the appeal in part and set aside the award in so far as it directed the payment of 50 of the total emoluments for the strike period but maintain the rest of the award.

We therefore allow the appeal in part and set aside the award in so far as it directed the payment of 50 of the total emoluments for the strike period but maintain the rest of the award.

The managements case that the workmen were charged only the cost price of rice has rightly been rejected by the Tribunal. The fact that workmen were not compelled to purchase rice from the management is hardly material the management had opened the shop to help the workmen and if it is found that it charged excess rates, in fairness, the workmen must be reimbursed.
We therefore allow the appeal in part and set aside the award in so far as it directed the payment of 50 of the total emoluments for the strike period but maintain the rest of the award.
The award in so far as it directed refund of the excess amount collected on the basis of the figures found by the Tribunal cannot therefore be successfully challenged.
We therefore allow the appeal in part and set aside the award in so far as it directed the payment of 50 of the total emoluments for the strike period but maintain the rest of the award.

anchor.surface_text: The admitted fact that it had been regularly paid year after year for many years till it was stopped in 1949 is sufficient to establish the workmens case that payment of a proper cumbly allowance had become a part of their conditions of service.
We therefore allow the appeal in part and set aside the award in so far as it directed the payment of 50 of the total emoluments for the strike period but maintain the rest of the award.

anchor.surface_text: We do not think that the mere fact that the workmen did not raise any dispute on the managements refusal to implement this condition of service till August 9, 1955, would be a sufficient reason to refuse them such payment. The management had acted arbitrarily and illegally in stopping payment of these allowances from 1949 to 1954. They cannot now be heard to say that they should not be asked to pay it merely because the years have already gone by.
We therefore allow the appeal in part and set aside the award in so far as it directed the payment of 50 of the total emoluments for the strike period but maintain the rest of the award.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal has acted justly in directing payment of the allowances to the workmen for the years 1949 to 1953. The correctness of the rates awarded by the Tribunal is not challenged before us. The Tribunals award on this issue also is therefore maintained.
We therefore allow the appeal in part and set aside the award in so far as it directed the payment of 50 of the total emoluments for the strike period but maintain the rest of the award.

edges.explanation: General holding h7 that indiscriminate use without exhausting remedies like reference not justified supports specific holding h8 on this strike being unjustified for same reason.
Principle in h7 supports h9 denial of wages based on unjustified strike.

anchor.surface_text: While on the one hand it has to be remembered that strike is a legitimate and sometimes unavoidable weapon in the hands of labour it is equally important to remember that indiscriminate and hasty use of this weapon should not be encouraged. It will not be right for labour to think that for any kind of demand a strike can be commenced with impunity without exhausting reasonable avenues for peaceful achievement of their objects.
We therefore allow the appeal in part and set aside the award in so far as it directed the payment of 50 of the total emoluments for the strike period but maintain the rest of the award.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to see how the strike in such circumstances could be held to be justified. The Tribunal itself appears to have been in two minds on the question. Its conclusion appears to be that the strike though not fully justified, was half justified and half unjustified we find it difficult to appreciate this curious concept of half justification.

anchor.surface_text: We are bound to hold in view of the circumstances mentioned above that the Tribunal erred in holding that the strike was at least partially justified. The error is so serious that we are bound in the interests of justice to set aside the decision. There is, in our view, no escape from the conclusion that the strike was unjustified and so the workmen are not entitled to any wages for the strike period.
